2,700 mile range |Ship range=cruise 14 knots; 6,100 mile range |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity= |Ship troops= |Ship complement=12 officers, 63 enlisted |Ship crew= |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors=2 x AN/SPS-64 |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*1 × [[M242 Bushmaster|Mk 38 25mm machine gun]] *2 × [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2HB .50 caliber machine gun]] |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft=[[HH-65 Dolphin]] |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |} [[Image:USCG Steadfast.jpg|thumb|200px|left|USCGC ''Steadfast'' (WMEC-623) pier-side at [[Astoria, Oregon]].]]
'''USCGC ''Steadfast'' (WMEC-623)''' is a [[United States Coast Guard]] [[Medium Endurance Cutter|medium endurance cutter]] and has served the United States for over 40 years. Commissioned in 1968, ''Steadfast'' was home ported in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] for her first 24 years of service. In 1992, she was decommissioned for Major Maintenance Availability (MMA) to extend her service another 25 years. Following MMA in February 1994, ''Steadfast'' was re-commissioned and home ported in [[Astoria, Oregon]].
Since commissioning in 1968, ''Steadfast'' has completed over 330 Search and Rescue cases, interdicted over 1.6 million pounds of marijuana and 27,700 pounds of cocaine, seized over 65 vessels, and stopped over 3500 undocumented migrants on the high seas from entering the United States. ''Steadfast'' was the first, and is one of only two cutters awarded the gold marijuana leaf, symbolizing one million pounds of marijuana seized. Legend holds ''Steadfast'' was named "El Tiburon Blanco" (Spanish for "The White Shark") by Colombian drug smugglers in the 1970s for being such a nemesis to their illegal drug operations. ''Steadfast''{{'}}s crew uses the symbol of "El Tiburon Blanco" as one of their logos to epitomize ''Steadfast''{{'}}s aggressive law enforcement posture.<ref>[http://www.uscg.mil/pacarea/cgcsteadfast/main.htm United States Coast Guard]</ref>
On 21 September 1978, [[Douglas DC-3]] N407D of [[Argosy Airlines]] crashed into the [[Caribbean Sea]] whilst on a [[ferry flying|ferry flight]] from [[Fort Lauderdale – Hollywood International Airport|Fort Lauderdale International Airport]] to [[José Martí International Airport]], [[Havana]]. All four people on board were killed.<ref name=ASN210978>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19780921-0 |title=N407D Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=1 August 2010}}</ref> The aircraft disappeared off radar screens at 12:43 [[UTC-5|local time]] (17:43 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]). A search was initiated, which ''Steadfast'' coordinated, but was called off on 24 September without any trace of N407D being found.<ref name=N407D>{{cite web|url=http://www.bermuda-triangle.org/html/into_the_blue.html |title=Into the Blue |publisher=Bermuda Triangle |accessdate=2 August 2010}}</ref>
